case_name: Appellant Company v. Kundlik Tulsiram Bhosle

facts.text: Kundlik Tulsiram Bhosle was engaged as a temporary Motor driver in the service of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Kundik Tulairam Bhosle, who is the third respondent before us, was engaged as a temporary Motor driver in the service of the appellant.

facts.text: Kundlik was appointed on December 22, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed on December 22, 1954, and it was expressly mentioned in the letter of appointment that until such time as he was companyfirmed by an order in writing his services were liable to be terminated at any time without numberice or companypensation and without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Appointment letter stated services liable to be terminated at any time without notice or compensation until confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: and it was expressly mentioned in the letter of appointment that until such time as he was companyfirmed by an order in writing his services were liable to be terminated at any time without numberice or companypensation and without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Kundlik was dismissed from service by order dated December 19, 1955, effective December 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated December 19, 1955, he was dismissed from service from December 20, 1955.

facts.text: Charge sheet served on Kundlik on November 9 alleging on November 14 he allowed Conductor Vyankati to carry five passengers without ticket and allowed unauthorized driver Sheikh Akbar to drive the Bus.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before this step was taken by the management, Kundlik had been served with a charge sheet that on November 14, when he was in charge of a Bus as a driver he allowed Conductor Vyankati to carry five passengers without ticket and also allowed an unauthorized driver Sheikh Akbar to drive the Bus.

facts.text: Kundlik submitted explanation on November 19.

anchor.surface_text: The charge sheet was served on Kundlik on November 9,and on November 19, he submitted an explantion.

facts.text: Management held enquiry by Depot Manager and found charges established.

anchor.surface_text: According to the management an enquiry was thereafter held by the Depot Manager and the charges were found established.

facts.text: Employee made application under s.16 of C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 to Labour Commissioner alleging dismissal illegal without enquiry, praying reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: Kundlik, the employee made an application under s,16 of the C. P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947, before the Labour Commissioner, Madhya Pradesh, Nagpur, alleging that his dismissal had number been preceded by an enquiry, that he had been illegally dismissed and - praying for reinstatement-

facts.text: Appellant pleaded in written statement that enquiry was properly held and dismissal legal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded in its written statement that an enquiry had been properly held and that ,the order of dismissal was legally made.

facts.text: Assistant Labour Commissioner doubted whether enquiry held properly but held employee guilty on charge of carrying passengers without tickets, dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Labour Commissioner, who has the powers of the Labour Commissioner, under s.16, dealt with the application. He was of opinion that there were sufficient grounds to doubt whether an enquiry was really made by the Non.applicant Management... Accordingly he dismissed the applications.

facts.text: State Industrial Court on appeal set aside LC order, held LC had no jurisdiction to hold enquiry, directed reinstatement with back wages.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the -employee moved the State Industrial Court, Nagpur. That Court felt that it would number be justified in interfering with the findings of the Labour Commissioner that numberenquiry had been held by the Management and that the Assistant Labour Commissioner had numberjuris- diction to hold an enquiry. In this view. the Court set aside the order of the Labour Commissioner and made an order directing reinstatement of the employee with back wages.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Arts. 226/227 before Bombay High Court at Nagpur to quash Industrial Court order.

anchor.surface_text: It was against this order that the employer moved the High Court of Bombay on the ground that the Assistant Labour Commissioner and the State Industrial Court had erred...

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ application on October 17, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 17, 1959, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No, 59 of 1959.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave, Civil Appeal No. 504 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 504 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 17, 1959, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No, 59 of 1959.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that no enquiry was not held finding by LC was perverse, enquiry was held, restored LC order.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion of the Assistant Labour Commissioner that there are sufficient ground to doubt whether an enquiry was really made must therefore be held to be perverse... We have accordingly companye to the companyclusion that the High Court ought to have held that there was a proper enquiry held against this employee... Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court...

facts.text: Management produced before LC evidence from enquiry: statements of Kundlik, two conductors signed.

anchor.surface_text: The management produced before the Assistant Labour Commissioner papers showing the evidence that was claimed to have been recorded during such enquiry. According to this record, three persons were examined during the enquiry-the employee Kundalik himself, one Conductor Surewar and the Conductor Vyankati. At the bottom of IX Bombay Law Reporter. 72. IX Bombay Law Reporter, 1422. this, paper there is Kundaliks signature and also Vyankatis signature.

facts.text: Employee claimed signature obtained on blank paper.

anchor.surface_text: The employees case was that his signature had been obtained on a blank paper and the document was then written up.

facts.text: LC did not believe forgery but doubted due to no enquiring officer signature.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Labour Commissioner himself has number said that he believes the explanation of the employee that his signature had been obtained on a blank paper. He was however impressed by the fact that signature of Kandalik and Vyankati only were obtained and the Enquiring Officers signature doei number appear on the paper

facts.text: No standing orders on dismissal by appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the appellant companycern had numberstanding order on the matter of dismissal.

facts.text: Sheikh Akbar was a fully licensed driver of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: the Assistant Labour Commissioner came to the companyclusion that the employee companyld, number be held guilty of the charge of allowing an unauthorised person to drive the vehicle as Sheikh Akbar was a fully licensed driver of the Company

facts.text: Guilt on carrying five passengers without tickets established by LC.

anchor.surface_text: but that his guilt on the other charge that he carried five passengers without tickets was fully established.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by DAS GUPTA, J. on August 21, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. August 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: High Court held it could not interfere with finding of no enquiry under Arts 226/227.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of opinion that it companyld number exercise its powers under Arts. 226. and 227 of the Constitution to interfere with the finding of the Assistant Labour Commissioner and the Revisional Court that numberenquiry had been held.

facts.text: Employee did not claim improper enquiry but only no enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: His case, as already statated, was that numberenquiry had been held at all. No alternative case that the enquiry held was improper because he had number been allowed to crossexamine witnesses or to adduce evidence was made by him.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with industrial disputes under the Industrial Disputes Act and other similar legislation, Industrial Tribunals, Labour Courts, Appellate Tribunals and finally this Court have by a series of decisions laid down the law that even though under contract law, pure and simple, an employee may be liable to dismissal, without anything more, industrial adjudication would set aside the order of dismissal and direct reinstatement of the workman where dismissal was made without proper and fair enquiry by the management or where even if such enquiry had been held the decision of the Enquiring Officer Was perverse or the action of the management was mala fide or amounted to unfair labour practice or victimisation

concepts.interpretation: Dismissal without proper enquiry invalid even for temporary employees under industrial law, despite contract terms

concepts.interpretation: Ordinary contract law allows dismissal without enquiry, but overridden by industrial law

issues.text: The question is whether the dismissal of the employee without an enquiry was in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the appellant companycern had numberstanding order on the matter of dismissal. The question is whether the dismissal of the employee without an enquiry was in accordance with law. If it is number, the Labour Commissioner would have jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether it was not necessary in law to hold an enquiry before dismissing the employee in view of the terms of his employment and so the Industrial Court was not justified in interfering with the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Three points have been urged on behalf of the appellant. The first is that it was number necessary in law to hold an enquiry before dismissing the employee in view of the terms of his employment and so in exercising jurisdiction under s- 16 of the C. P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, the Industrial Court was number justified in interfering with the order of dismissal.

issues.text: Whether, if an enquiry by the management was necessary, the Assistant Labour Commissioner had jurisdiction to hold an enquiry himself.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was urged that in any case, if it be held that an enquiry by the management was necessary in law it should be proper to hold that the Assistant Labour Commissioner had jurisdiction to hold enquiry himself.

issues.text: Whether the view taken by the Assistant Labour Commissioner that no enquiry had been held was perverse and the High Court ought to have set aside that finding.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it was urged that the view taken by the Assistant Labour Commissioner that numberenquiry had been held was perverse and the High Court ought to have set aside that finding and given relief -on the basis that an enquiry had been properly held.

issues.text: Whether the High Court could exercise powers under Arts. 226 and 227 to interfere with the finding that no enquiry had been held.

anchor.surface_text: powers under Arts. 226. and 227 of the Constitution to interfere with the finding

arguments.claim: The Industrial Court erred in thinking it was bound by the Labour Commissioner's perverse finding; error apparent on face of record warranting High Court correction

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court erred in thinking that it was bound by this decision of the Labour Commissioner and this error on its part was, in our opinion, an error so apparent on the face of the record that was proper and reasonable for the High Court to companyrect that error.

holdings.text: The conclusion of the Assistant Labour Commissioner that there are sufficient grounds to doubt whether an enquiry was really made must therefore be held to be perverse.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion of the Assistant Labour Commissioner that there are sufficient ground to doubt whether an enquiry was really made must therefore be held to be perverse. It has often been pointed out by eminent judges that when it appears to an appellate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed statements of employee and two witnesses produced; implausible forgery without evidence; omission of enquiring officer's signature not sufficient to doubt entire enquiry; no reasonable judicial person could reach opposite conclusion.

holdings.text: The decision of the Assistant Labour Commissioner that no enquiry had been held by the management amounts to a clear error in law.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Assistant Labour Commissioner that no enquiry had been, held by the management amounts therefore, in our opinion, to a clear error in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perverse finding equates to mis-conception of law by authority acting judicially.

holdings.text: The Industrial Court erred in thinking that it was bound by this decision of the Labour Commissioner and this error was an error so apparent on the face of the record that it was proper and reasonable for the High Court to correct that error.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court erred in thinking that it was bound by this decision of the Labour Commissioner and this error on its part was, in our opinion, an error so apparent on the face of the record that was proper and reasonable for the High Court to correct that error.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding itself to perverse finding of fact by lower authority constitutes legal error visible on record.

holdings.text: The High Court ought to have held that there was a proper enquiry held against this employee and the management dismissed him on finding on that enquiry that the two charges against him had been fully proved, and that there was no reason to think that the management acted mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: We have accordingly come to the conclusion that the High Court ought to have held that there was a proper enquiry held against this employee and the management dismissed him on finding on that enquiry that the two charges against him had been fully proved,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perverse lower findings correctable under writ jurisdiction; evidence supports proper enquiry and guilt.

holdings.text: Prima facie, it was necessary in law to hold an enquiry before dismissing the employee despite the terms of his employment.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore primafacie indeed to think that the first contention raised by the learned Attorney-General that it was number necessary in law to hold an enquiry before dismissing this employee-in view of the terms of his employment, cannot be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'In accordance with law' in Schedule 2 includes industrial law evolved by courts requiring fair enquiry before dismissal, overriding pure contract law for master-servant.

holdings.text: Prima facie, even if no proper enquiry held by management, the Labour Commissioner had jurisdiction to hold an enquiry himself.

anchor.surface_text: At the same time we are inclined to think that there is considerable force in the second contention that even though a proper enquiry was not held by the management the Labour Commissioner had jurisdiction to hold an enquiry himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 16 allows enquiry into whether dismissal contravenes law; sufficient for LC to adduce evidence if management failed.

holdings.text: It is not open to the respondent to argue that even if an enquiry had been held, the employee had no opportunity of cross-examining witnesses or adducing evidence, as this was not the employee's case.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent it was sought to be argued,that even if an enquiry had been held it has not been shown that the employee bad an opportunity of cross-examining. witnesses or adducing evidence of his own. It is not open however for the learned Counsel to raise the question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Employee's consistent case was no enquiry at all; no alternative pleading of improper enquiry; new point not arguable in appeal.

For the reasons mentioned above, we are inclined to think, with respect, that this view is number companyrect. We think it unnecessary however to discuss this matter more closely or record our definite and final conclusion on these questions as for the reasons to be presently stated we are of opinion that in any case the third ground raised on behalf of the appellant should succeed.
